title: Statistics
text:
Key Topics

Data Collection
Methods of gathering information:

Surveys and questionnaires
Observations
Experiments
Sampling methods
Primary vs. secondary data

Example: To find out students’ favorite sports, we could conduct a survey of the class.


Organizing Data
Ways to arrange and present data:

Frequency tables
Tally charts
Grouping data into intervals
Creating categories

Example: Tally chart of favorite colors in class


Displaying Data
Visual representations of data:

Bar graphs and column graphs
Line graphs
Pie charts
Pictographs
Dot plots
Stem-and-leaf plots

Example: A bar graph showing the number of students who prefer different subjects.


Measures of Central Tendency
Finding typical or middle values:

Mean: The average of all values

Formula: Sum of all values ÷ Number of values

Median: The middle value when data is ordered
Mode: The most frequent value

Example: Find the mean of: 4, 7, 5, 9, 5
Solution: Mean = (4 + 7 + 5 + 9 + 5) ÷ 5 = 30 ÷ 5 = 6


Range and Spread
Understanding how data varies:

Range: Maximum value - Minimum value
Quartiles and interquartile range
Outliers (unusual values)

Example: For the data set 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, the range is 11 - 3 = 8


Interpreting Data
Making sense of statistical information:

Reading and understanding graphs
Drawing conclusions from data
Identifying trends and patterns
Understanding bias and misleading graphs



Box-and-Whisker Plots
Visualizing the distribution of data:

Five-number summary (minimum, Q1, median, Q3, maximum)
Identifying the spread of data
Comparing data sets

title: Probability
text: Probability is the study of chance and likelihood. It helps us predict and understand uncertain events in mathematics and everyday life.

title: Probability
text: Probability is the study of chance and likelihood. It helps us predict and understand uncertain events in mathematics and everyday life.

title: Probability
text:
Key Topics

Basic Probability Concepts
Understanding chance:

Probability measures how likely an event is to occur
Probability scale: 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain)
Expressing probability as fractions, decimals, and percentages

Example: The probability of rolling a 3 on a standard die is \(\frac{1}{6}\)


Theoretical Probability
Calculating probability using logic:

Formula: \(P(\text{event}) = \frac{\text{number of favorable outcomes}}{\text{total number of possible outcomes}}\)
Sample space (all possible outcomes)
Equally likely outcomes

Example: What is the probability of drawing a heart from a standard deck of 52 cards?
Solution: \(P(\text{heart}) = \frac{13}{52} = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25 = 25\%\)


Experimental Probability
Probability based on trials and experiments:

Conducting experiments
Recording results
Calculating relative frequency
Comparing theoretical and experimental probability

Example: If you flip a coin 50 times and get 28 heads, the experimental probability is \(\frac{28}{50} = 0.56\)


Probability Language
Describing likelihood:

Impossible (probability = 0)
Unlikely (probability between 0 and 0.5)
Even chance (probability = 0.5)
Likely (probability between 0.5 and 1)
Certain (probability = 1)



Simple Events
Working with single outcomes:

Probability of simple events
Complementary events: \(P(\text{not A}) = 1 - P(\text{A})\)
Mutually exclusive events

Example: If the probability of rain is 0.3, what is the probability it won’t rain?
Solution: \(P(\text{no rain}) = 1 - 0.3 = 0.7\)


Tree Diagrams
Visualizing probability:

Representing outcomes systematically
Calculating probabilities of multiple events
Understanding combined events



Probability in Games
Understanding fairness and strategy:

Fair vs. unfair games
Expected outcomes
Making predictions

Example: In a game where you win if you roll a 5 or 6, the probability of winning is \(\frac{2}{6} = \frac{1}{3}\)

If \(P(\text{event}) = 0.65\), find \(P(\text{not event})\)
You flip a coin twice. What is the probability of getting two heads?

title: Mapping the School Farm
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
Learning Goals

Create a digital farm map using layers.
Add points, lines, and areas with clear labels.
Measure distances and paddock areas accurately.
Export or print a clean map for your workbook.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
1. Getting Started

Go to https://www.google.co.nz/mymaps and sign in to your Google account. If you do not have an account, create one.
Click “Create a new map”.
Click “Untitled map” to rename your map (for example, “Kaikorai Valley College School Farm”).

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
2. Set Up Layers
Layers let you separate existing features from proposed work. You can turn layers on or off using the checkbox next to each layer.

Rename the first layer to Existing. Use this for current paddocks, dams, fences, buildings, and water points.
Click “Add layer” and name it Proposed for future work such as new planting or fencing.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
3. Locate the Farm

Use the search bar to type in the school address, or zoom using the mouse wheel and the + / - buttons.
Click the arrow next to Base map and choose Satellite for a clear aerial view.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
4. Add Farm Features

A. Markers (Point Features)
Use markers for water tanks, sheds, gates, troughs, or trees.

Click the Marker icon under the search bar.
Click the exact spot on the map.
Give the marker a clear title, then save.




B. Lines (Fences, Tracks, Waterways)

Click the Line icon (right of the marker icon) and choose “Add line or shape”.
Click along the path of the fence or creek.
Press Enter to finish the line and add a title.




C. Areas (Paddocks, Orchards, Bush)

Start the same way as a line.
Click around the boundary and then click the starting point to close the shape.
Add a title and save.



D. Edit or Delete Features
After saving a feature, a popup lets you edit color, line width, transparency, and description. You can also attach a photo or delete the feature using the trash bin icon.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
5. Measure Distances and Areas
The Measurement tool (ruler icon) helps you check distances or paddock sizes.

Click the ruler icon on the far right of the toolbar.
Click a starting point, then add points to measure a path.
For a polygon, close the shape to see both perimeter and area (in hectares).
Press Enter to finish a straight line measurement.
To stop measuring, click the hand icon or click anywhere on the screen.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
6. Export or Print Your Map

Option A: Print Map (Recommended)

Click the three vertical dots next to your map name.
Choose “Print map”.
Pick paper size, orientation, and output type, then click Print.
A new PDF preview opens in your browser. Use the print icon to save as PDF or print.




Option B: Screenshot (Snipping Tool)
Windows

Open Snipping Tool from the Start menu search.
Click New, then drag to select the area.
Save the image and insert it into your workbook.

Mac

Press Shift + Command + 4.
Drag to select the area.
The screenshot saves to the desktop for inserting into your workbook.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
Map Checklist

Your map has a clear title.
Layers include Existing and Proposed.
Features are labeled with correct names.
At least one line and one area are mapped.
Measurements are used to check a distance or area.
Export is clean and readable.

title: Farm Mapping Homework
text:
In this homework assignment, you will create a PDF map of the school farm using Google My Maps. You will learn how to add important features to your map, including an arrow, scale, and legend.




Create Your Map:

Follow the instructions provided in the index.Rmd file to create your farm map using Google My Maps.

Add Features:

Once your map is created, you need to add the following features:

Arrow: Indicate a specific direction on your map.
Scale: Show the scale of your map to help viewers understand distances.
Legend: Create a legend that explains the symbols and colors used on your map.


Export Your Map:

After adding the features, export your map as a PDF. Make sure the arrow, scale, and legend are clearly visible in the exported document.






Explain why it is important to include a scale on your map. How does it help the viewer?
Describe the purpose of a legend in a map. What information should be included in your legend for the school farm map?




This homework aligns with the following areas of the New Zealand Curriculum:

Geography: Understand how to represent geographical information using maps.
Mathematics: Apply measurement concepts in real-world contexts.

For more information, visit the New Zealand Curriculum website: New Zealand Curriculum

Note: Ensure you follow the guidelines and submit your homework by the due date. Happy mapping!

title: Algebra
text: Algebra is the language of mathematics. It allows us to describe patterns, relationships, and solve problems using symbols and variables.

title: Algebra
text:
Key Topics

Variables and Expressions
Understanding algebraic notation:

Variables represent unknown or changing values
Writing algebraic expressions
Evaluating expressions by substitution

Example: If \(x = 5\), evaluate \(3x + 7\)
Solution: \(3(5) + 7 = 15 + 7 = 22\)


Simplifying Expressions
Working with algebraic terms:

Collecting like terms
Expanding brackets
Factorizing simple expressions

Example: Simplify \(5x + 3 - 2x + 7\)
Solution: \(5x - 2x + 3 + 7 = 3x + 10\)


Solving Linear Equations
Finding unknown values:

One-step equations
Two-step equations
Equations with brackets
Equations with variables on both sides

Example: Solve \(2x + 5 = 13\)
Solution: \[\begin{align}
2x + 5 &= 13 \\
2x &= 8 \\
x &= 4
\end{align}\]


Patterns and Sequences
Recognizing and describing patterns:

Number patterns
Geometric patterns
Finding the nth term
Linear sequences

Example: Find the next term in the sequence: 3, 7, 11, 15, …
Solution: The pattern increases by 4 each time, so the next term is 19.


Graphing Linear Relationships
Visualizing equations:

Plotting points on a coordinate plane
Drawing straight line graphs
Understanding gradient (slope)
Finding the equation of a line

Example: Graph the equation \(y = 2x + 1\)

title: Year 9 Mathematics: Basics Consolidation
text:
Complete the following sets to consolidate your understanding of key mathematical terms. Read the Worked Example carefully before starting the questions.










Term
Definition
Picture/Example




BEDMAS
The order of operations used to solve equations.
Brackets, Exponents, Division, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction.


Integers
All whole numbers, including positive, negative, and zero.
\(... -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 ...\)


Multiple
The result of multiplying a number by an integer.
Multiples of 5: \(5, 10, 15, 20...\)


Factor
A number that divides into another number exactly (without a remainder).
Factors of 10: \(1, 2, 5, 10\).


Power
The product of multiplying a number by itself several times.
\(2^3\) (which is \(2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8\)).


Exponent
The small number written above a base that tells you how many times to use the base in a multiplication.
In \(5^2\), the 2 is the exponent.


Index
Another name for an exponent or power. (The plural is “Indices”).
\(x^4\) — the 4 is the index.


Square root
A number that, when multiplied by itself, gives the original number.
\(\sqrt{25} = 5\) (because \(5 \times 5 = 25\)).


Numerator
The top number in a fraction. It shows how many parts you have.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 3 is the numerator.


Denominator
The bottom number in a fraction. It shows how many equal parts the whole is divided into.
In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the 4 is the denominator.


Mixed fraction
A number consisting of an integer and a proper fraction.
\(2\frac{1}{2}\)


Improper fraction
A fraction where the numerator is larger than (or equal to) the denominator.
\(\frac{5}{2}\)


Equivalent fraction
Fractions that look different but have the same value.
\(\frac{1}{2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{4}{8}\)

Mass: grams (g), kilograms (kg), tonnes (t)
Capacity: millilitres (mL), litres (L)
Time: seconds, minutes, hours, days

Example: Convert 2.5 km to metres.
Solution: 2.5 km = 2.5 × 1000 = 2500 m


Perimeter
Measuring the distance around shapes:

Perimeter of rectangles and squares
Perimeter of triangles and other polygons
Perimeter of composite shapes

Example: Find the perimeter of a rectangle with length 8 cm and width 5 cm.
Solution: Perimeter = 2(8 + 5) = 2(13) = 26 cm


Area
Measuring the space inside shapes:

Area of rectangles and squares: \(A = l \times w\)
Area of triangles: \(A = \frac{1}{2} \times b \times h\)
Area of circles: \(A = \pi r^2\)
Area of composite shapes

Example: Find the area of a triangle with base 10 cm and height 6 cm.
Solution: \(A = \frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 6 = 30 \text{ cm}^2\)


Volume
Measuring the space inside 3D objects:

Volume of rectangular prisms: \(V = l \times w \times h\)
Volume of cubes: \(V = s^3\)
Volume of cylinders: \(V = \pi r^2 h\)
Capacity and volume relationship

Example: Find the volume of a cube with side length 4 cm.
Solution: \(V = 4^3 = 64 \text{ cm}^3\)


Surface Area
Measuring the total area of all faces:

Surface area of rectangular prisms
Surface area of cubes
Using nets to find surface area

Example: Find the surface area of a cube with side length 3 cm.
Solution: A cube has 6 faces, each with area \(3^2 = 9\) cm²
Total surface area = \(6 \times 9 = 54\) cm²


Scale and Maps
Working with scaled representations:

Understanding scale ratios
Using scales to find actual distances
Map reading

Example: On a map with scale 1:50000, a distance is 4 cm. What is the actual distance?
Solution: Actual distance = 4 × 50000 = 200000 cm = 2 km

title: Number and Operations
text:
Lesson notes and practice

Week 1 Thu - Unit launch, number line warm-up, baseline check
Notes

Review integer placement on a number line and compare values using <, >, and =.
Emphasize direction: right is greater, left is smaller.
Baseline check focuses on place value and simple operations.

Worked examples

Place and compare: \(-3\) and \(2\).

\(-3\) is left of \(2\), so \(-3 < 2\).

Distance from zero: compare \(-7\) and \(5\).

\(|-7| = 7\) and \(|5| = 5\), so \(-7\) is further from zero.

Order these: \(4, -1, 0, -5\).

\(-5, -1, 0, 4\).


Practice questions

Plot \(-6, -2, 0, 3, 7\) on a number line.
Which is greater: \(-4\) or \(-9\)?
Order: \(6, -3, -8, 1\) from least to greatest.
Write a number between \(-2\) and \(3\).
True or false: \(-1 > -3\).
What is the distance between \(-4\) and \(2\)?
Place value: in \(54.203\), what is the value of the 2?
Evaluate: \(3 + (-5)\).



Week 1 Fri - Place value review, decimals as parts of a whole
Notes

Place value extends to tenths, hundredths, thousandths.
Decimals represent parts of a whole and can be compared by place value.

Worked examples

Write \(3\) tenths and \(7\) hundredths as a decimal: \(0.37\).
Compare \(0.5\) and \(0.47\): \(0.50 > 0.47\).
Expand \(12.304\) by place value: \(10 + 2 + 0.3 + 0.004\).

Practice questions

Write \(6\) tenths and \(2\) thousandths as a decimal.
Which is larger: \(0.209\) or \(0.29\)?
Expand \(4.508\) by place value.
Write \(7.03\) in words.
Compare using <, >, =: \(1.25\) and \(1.205\).
What is the value of the 8 in \(3.081\)?
Order: \(0.4, 0.04, 0.44, 0.404\).
Convert \(3\) and \(5\) tenths to a decimal.



Week 2 Mon - Rounding decimals to place value
Notes

Identify the rounding digit and look one place to the right.
If the next digit is 5 or more, round up; otherwise round down.

Worked examples

Round \(6.247\) to the nearest tenth: \(6.2\).
Round \(12.995\) to the nearest hundredth: \(13.00\).
Round \(0.0499\) to the nearest hundredth: \(0.05\).

Practice questions

Round \(4.738\) to the nearest tenth.
Round \(9.995\) to the nearest hundredth.
Round \(15.039\) to the nearest hundredth.
Round \(0.504\) to the nearest tenth.
Round \(3.14159\) to the nearest thousandth.
Round \(62.499\) to the nearest whole number.
Round \(1.205\) to the nearest tenth.
Round \(7.444\) to the nearest hundredth.



Week 2 Tue - Significant figures
Notes

All non-zero digits are significant.
Zeros between non-zero digits are significant.
Leading zeros are not significant.
Trailing zeros are significant only if a decimal point is shown.

Worked examples

\(0.00450\) has 3 significant figures.
\(1200\) has 2 significant figures; \(1200.\) has 4 significant figures.
Round \(0.06749\) to 2 significant figures: \(0.067\).

Practice questions

How many significant figures are in \(0.03040\)?
How many significant figures are in \(7050\)?
Round \(3.4567\) to 3 significant figures.
Round \(98.76\) to 2 significant figures.
Round \(0.009912\) to 2 significant figures.
Write \(0.004560\) with 3 significant figures.
True or false: \(100.0\) has 4 significant figures.
Round \(12,450\) to 3 significant figures.



Week 2 Wed - Recurring decimals and notation
Notes

Recurring decimals repeat forever; use a dot or bar to show the repeat.
Convert fractions to decimals by division.
Recognize common recurring forms like \(\frac{1}{3} = 0.\overline{3}\).

Worked examples

\(\frac{1}{3} = 0.\overline{3}\).
\(\frac{2}{11} = 0.\overline{18}\).
\(0.\overline{6} = \frac{2}{3}\).

Practice questions

Convert \(\frac{1}{6}\) to a decimal (recurring).
Convert \(\frac{5}{9}\) to a decimal.
Write \(0.\overline{72}\) as a fraction in simplest form.
Which is larger: \(0.\overline{4}\) or \(0.\overline{5}\)?
Convert \(0.\overline{3}\) to a fraction.
Convert \(\frac{7}{12}\) to a decimal (recurring or terminating).
Identify the repeating block in \(0.142857142857...\).
True or false: every fraction gives a terminating decimal.



Week 2 Thu - Scientific notation and powers of 10
Notes

Scientific notation is \(a \times 10^n\) where \(1 \le a < 10\).
Moving the decimal left makes \(n\) positive; right makes \(n\) negative.

Worked examples

\(3,500,000 = 3.5 \times 10^6\).
\(0.00072 = 7.2 \times 10^{-4}\).
\(4.2 \times 10^3 = 4200\).

Practice questions

Write \(56,000\) in scientific notation.
Write \(0.0045\) in scientific notation.
Convert \(9.1 \times 10^2\) to standard form.
Convert \(3.07 \times 10^{-3}\) to standard form.
Which is larger: \(6.2 \times 10^5\) or \(8.1 \times 10^4\)?
Write \(12,300,000\) in scientific notation.
Write \(0.0000005\) in scientific notation.
Estimate \(4.9 \times 10^3 + 3.1 \times 10^3\).



Week 2 Fri - No school
Notes

No lesson (public holiday).

Optional practice

Review rounding to the nearest tenth.
Convert \(0.\overline{3}\) to a fraction.
Write \(45,000\) in scientific notation.
Round \(0.0999\) to 2 significant figures.



Week 3 Mon - Mixed practice: rounding and significant figures
Notes

Choose rounding to place value or significant figures based on the question.
Check reasonableness after rounding.

Worked examples

Round \(0.006789\) to 2 significant figures: \(0.0068\).
Round \(45.376\) to the nearest tenth: \(45.4\).
Round \(98,650\) to 3 significant figures: \(98,700\).

Practice questions

Round \(0.0009401\) to 2 significant figures.
Round \(65.05\) to 3 significant figures.
Round \(4.995\) to the nearest hundredth.
Round \(3.0049\) to 2 significant figures.
Round \(12,340\) to 2 significant figures.
Round \(0.05199\) to the nearest thousandth.
Round \(8.888\) to 2 significant figures.



Week 3 Tue - Scientific notation and calculator checks
Notes

Use calculator EXP or EE button for powers of 10.
Check if answers are reasonable by comparing magnitude.

Worked examples

\(6.5 \times 10^4 = 65,000\).
\(0.0000092 = 9.2 \times 10^{-6}\).
\(3.1 \times 10^5 + 2.4 \times 10^5 = 5.5 \times 10^5\).

Practice questions

Convert \(8.03 \times 10^7\) to standard form.
Write \(0.000120\) in scientific notation.
Calculate: \(2.5 \times 10^3 + 4.8 \times 10^3\).
Calculate: \(7.2 \times 10^2 - 3.5 \times 10^2\).
Which is larger: \(1.2 \times 10^{-3}\) or \(9.5 \times 10^{-4}\)?
Convert \(4,600,000\) to scientific notation.
Convert \(6.7 \times 10^{-2}\) to standard form.
Estimate \(9.9 \times 10^6 - 1.1 \times 10^6\).



Week 3 Wed - Words for +, -, x, /
Notes

Identify operation words: add, sum, total; subtract, difference; multiply, product; divide, quotient.
Translate word problems into number sentences.

Worked examples

“The sum of 7 and 9” is \(7 + 9\).
“The difference between 15 and 6” is \(15 - 6\).
“The quotient of 48 and 6” is \(48 \div 6\).

Practice questions

Write a number sentence for: “The product of 8 and 5”.
Write a number sentence for: “The sum of 3, 7, and 12”.
Write a number sentence for: “12 less than 40”.
Write a number sentence for: “The quotient of 54 and 9”.
Write a number sentence for: “The difference between 100 and 35”.
Solve: “A packet has 24 stickers shared equally among 6 students”.
Solve: “A total of 45 apples are packed into 5 boxes equally”.
Solve: “A $12 discount is taken from a $65 item”.



Week 3 Thu - Integers
Notes

Use the number line to model integer addition and subtraction.
Adding a negative moves left; subtracting a negative moves right.

Worked examples

\(-4 + 7 = 3\).
\(-6 - 5 = -11\).
\(8 + (-12) = -4\).

\(5 + (-8)\)
\(-12 + 7\)
\(-6 - 4\)
\(9 - (-2)\)
\(-15 - (-5)\)
\(-7 + (-6)\)
\(14 + (-20)\)



Week 4 Mon - Order of operations
Notes

Use BEDMAS: Brackets, Exponents, Division/Multiplication, Addition/Subtraction.
Division and multiplication are done left to right, same for addition and subtraction.

Worked examples

\(3 + 4 \times 2 = 3 + 8 = 11\).
\((5 + 7) \div 3 = 12 \div 3 = 4\).
\(2^3 + 6 \times 2 = 8 + 12 = 20\).

\(20 - 6 \div 2\)

title: Ratios and Proportions
text: Ratios and proportions describe relationships between quantities. They are fundamental to understanding scaling, comparison, and many real-world applications.

title: Ratios and Proportions
text:
Key Topics

Understanding Ratios
Comparing quantities:

Ratios show the relationship between two or more quantities
Written as a:b or \(\frac{a}{b}\)
Simplifying ratios to simplest form
Part-to-part vs. part-to-whole ratios

Example: If there are 12 boys and 8 girls in a class, the ratio of boys to girls is 12:8 = 3:2


Equivalent Ratios
Finding equal ratios:

Multiplying or dividing both parts by the same number
Using ratio tables
Scaling up and down

Example: The ratio 4:6 is equivalent to 2:3 (dividing by 2) or 8:12 (multiplying by 2)


Proportions
When ratios are equal:

A proportion is an equation showing two ratios are equal
Cross multiplication to solve proportions
Direct proportion relationships

Example: Solve: \(\frac{3}{5} = \frac{x}{15}\)
Solution: \(5x = 3 \times 15\), so \(5x = 45\), therefore \(x = 9\)


Sharing in Ratios
Dividing quantities according to ratios:

Dividing amounts into given ratios
Finding total parts
Calculating each share

Example: Share $60 in the ratio 2:3
Solution: Total parts = 2 + 3 = 5
First share = $ = \(24\)
Second share = $ = \(36\)


Rates
Special ratios comparing different units:

Speed (distance per time)
Unit rates (per 1 unit)
Price per item
Comparing rates

Example: If you travel 180 km in 3 hours, your speed is:
\(\text{Speed} = \frac{180 \text{ km}}{3 \text{ hours}} = 60 \text{ km/h}\)


Scale Factors
Ratios in enlargement and reduction:

Scale drawings
Maps and models
Enlargement and reduction
Similar shapes

Example: A model car has a scale of 1:24. If the model is 15 cm long, what is the actual car length?
Solution: Actual length = 15 × 24 = 360 cm = 3.6 m


Direct Proportion
When quantities increase together:

If one doubles, the other doubles
Graphing direct proportion (straight line through origin)
Formula: \(y = kx\) where k is constant

Example: If 3 pens cost $6, how much do 7 pens cost?
Solution: Cost is proportional to number of pens
\(\frac{3}{6} = \frac{7}{x}\), so \(3x = 42\), therefore \(x = 14\) ($14)


Percentages as Ratios
Connecting percentages to ratios:

Percentages are ratios out of 100
Converting between percentages and ratios
Percentage increase and decrease
